Allow forum objects to both lock and unlock.

The primary purpose of this commit is to make the forum class slightly more
flexible.  Alex and I found that this flexibility is needed in our games, and
without this change we would have had to use something of a hack to work around
it.

This commit has not been tested, and so it probably does not work.
Minor changes to sprites.

Improve and simplify the network module.

This commit introduces two extensive changes to the network module.

The first redefines how identity numbers are assigned to pipes.  Now each pipe
has a unique id number, rather than each host having one.  This identity number
is assigned automatically by the host, and it is guaranteed to be the same on
both sides of the network.

The second simplifies the pipe interface by removing several features.  Pipes
no longer attempt to avoid the problems introduced by looped topologies, so the
receive() method no longer returns any information other than the message
itself.  For the same reason, the resend() method was removed.

This commits adds some test code for the sprite module.  I did find one bug,
but it was very small.

Create the conversation class.

The conversation class is part of the messaging module.  Unlike the forum,
which does not distinguish between any of its members, the conversation allows
for direct communication over a pipe.  I think this provides some nice balance.

Along with the additions to the messaging module, there were some small changes
to the networking module.  Pipes are still capable of assigning themselves ID
numbers, but I will remove that feature shortly.

Add guards against race conditions to the forum.

I modified the forum class so that only one remote message will be processed
each update cycle.  Remote messages have to potential to race with each other,
and this lowers the chance that these races will cause bugs.

And a safety/performance trade-off to the forum.

Normally the forum only delivers one incoming message every update cycle,
because this eliminates some potential race conditions.  However, for some
games this performance hit is unacceptable.  This commit adds an argument to
the forum constructor that can control this behavior.

Redesign the game engine to be more concrete.

This core game engine redesign was inspired by the desire to make it
more difficult to misuse and the need to make it more robust against cheaters.
Both of these goals were accomplished by allowing the game engine to implement
a more sophisticated messaging system than that supported by the forum.

This commit also includes a rearrangement and consolidation of some of the
other game engine modules.
Add a sandbox directory.
Add true division to the game engine.
Add the token proxy framework.

Begin adding the concept of actor proxies.

Actor proxies provide a way for the game engine to prevent message objects
from passing raw game tokens to the actors.  In many ways, these proxies are
the opposite of token proxies.

In fact, I found the need for actor proxies while trying to integrate token
proxies into the game.  I wanted messages to be able to directly call
methods in the actors, but this made it very easy for the message object to
provide raw tokens to the actors.

Add an actor proxy class.

These proxies allow messages to safely interact with the actors.  Messages
themselves are now tokens, and must pass themselves to actors as token proxies.

Stop using the actor proxy.

This was a hack, and it didn't solve the problem of tokens being passed from
the actors to the messages.  For now, I'm just depending on the message classes
to do the necessary conversions.

Check that messages are sent by the right players.

In the previous iterations of the game engine, it would have been possible for
malicious players to send messages as the wrong player.  To address, this, the
game engine now provides a player argument to the message.check() function.
The player is associated with each pipe as the game is being set up, so this
method cannot be hacked.

Add tougher restrictions to token access.

This commit implements a system for controlling token access based on method
decorators and metaclasses.  This system is stronger because it requires that
read-only methods be explicitly marked, and it also does not have any effect on
how tokens are pickled.

The unit tests supporting this new feature are present, but relatively weak.  I
need to develop a more comprehensive test set, perhaps composed of more
integration-type tests.

Remove greetings and guard the world better.

The greeting mechanism provided a way to associate a game object with a
particular actor, for the purpose of validating messages.  However, it
was a opaque and awkward, partially because it referenced game-specific
tokens from within the game engine.  This commit replaces the greeting
system with a simpler one based on ID numbers.  Each actor is assigned
an unique ID when the game starts up, and these IDs can be used to
validate messages.

This commit also adds more sophisticated safety checks to the game
world.  Token methods that aren't read-only should only be called from
messages.  Previously, the game engine could only enforce this if the
non-read-only methods were labeled with a decorator.  Any undecorated
methods were assumed to be read-only.  This was not a good approach,
because it was too easy to simply label nothing.

This commit forces the read-only methods to be labeled, and assumes all
token methods are dangerous by default.  This works by having a
metaclass effectively decorate all token methods behind the scenes.
Fortunately, metaclasses do not seem to have any effect on pickling.

This commit also creates a publisher/subscriber system for use with
messages.  In other words, Message.execute() and Message.notify() have
been removed.  The game engine will now search for methods with the
proper name (e.g. handle_create_soldier) in the world and actor objects,
and automatically invoke those.  This approach removes a lot of
boilerplate, but it also adds the potential for some more subtle bugs.
For example, if the name of a handler is misspelled, the handler will be
silently ignored.  This may be addressed in future commits.

Finally, this commit adds single player and multiplayer integration
tests.  Hopefully these tests will make future game engine development
easier and more robust.

Add helpful output to MultiplayerDebugger.

I added a logger object that intercepts all the output generated in each game
process, and displays it prefixed with the name of the process.  This makes it
much easier to see which game is outputting which message, especially when the
output is badly interleaved.  The logger can optionally copy the output stream
from each game into a different file.

Convert Pipe.receive() into a generator.

This fixes a very subtle bugs that occurs when two messages are received in the
same frame, and the second message contains a reference to a token that will be
created by the first.  The bug was caused because both messages were being
unpickled before being processed.  The second message then failed to be
unpickled because the first message had not yet been processed.  Returning an
iterator instead of a list solved the problem nicely.

This commit also adds some more documentation and a unit test specifically for
this bug.

Simplify the message system.

The previous commit removed Message.accept(), Message.reject(), and
Message.notify() in favor of a subscription system.  This commit reverts that
change, because the increased misdirection was more confusing than it was
worth.

This commit introduces a number of practical bug fixes that were required to

Make inheriting from ForumObserver less arcane.

For the benefit of Token, the last commit introduced a lot of weird
requirements for classes inheriting from ForumObserver.  In particular,
subclasses had to remember to call _configure_observer() at some point
in their constructors and a lot of attributes were being left undefined
to prevent unnecessary pickling.  I started to worry that both Token and
ForumObserver were getting rather brittle, so I made an effort to get
rid of these weird requirements.

I did this by using __getstate__ and __setstate__ to control which
attributes were getting pickled and by adding ForumObserver methods to
enable or disable forum observation.

This framework allows token extensions to easily attach callbacks to

Revamp how the end of the game is signaled.

This method makes a number of small architectural and aesthetic tweaks:

1. Indicate that the game is over by setting a flag in the world, rather
   than by waiting until all actors are finished.  I think this makes
   more sense, since the world is supposed to be the repository of
   shared state.

2. Change how messages add and remove tokens.  Previously there were
   special methods to override; now there are just methods to call.
   This new approach is more intuitive, but does require that the
   Message constructor be called by all subclasses.  That the
   constructor is actually called in not yet checked.

3. Raise an ApiUsageError for debugging with too many players.

4. Remove the GuiLoop.

5. Remove the predefined message classes.  These provided possible

Make the subscription system more robust.

1. Throw a nice error if user try to subscribe to things that aren't

2. Fix a bug in UnhandledSyncError.

Test hard sync errors upon adding or removing tokens.

These test revealed an architectural flaw that makes it impossible to
undo messages that remove tokens.  I'll have to address this issue
before the engine can be used to write games.

Implement the sent message cache.

Prior to this commit, messages received by the server would be broadcast
to all clients, including the client that sent the message in the first
place.  This turned out to be problematic (in addition to being slightly
wasteful) because that client would have already executed the message
and may not be able to unpickle it anymore.  For example, if the message
removed a token, that token would no longer no longer exist on the
client and an exception would be thrown when the client tried to
unpickle the message.

This commit adds a "sent message cache" to clients that keeps track of
the most recent messages sent by the client.  Instead of attaching its
response to the message itself, the server now responds with a separate
packet.  When the client receives such a response from the server, it
pops the relevant message off its sent message cache and handles the
response as appropriate.

All tests passed, but some naming conventions still have to be updated.

Replace soft/hard sync error nomenclature.

Instead these events are referred to as "sync responses" and "undo
responses".  I think the words "sync" and "undo" better describe what
users of the game engine API need to implement.

Overload the rshift operator to send messages.

I'm not really sure if this is a good idea.  The argument in favor is
that sending messages is a really common thing for actors to do, and
this syntax is less cluttered.  The argument in favor is that this is an
abuse of operator overloading, and that the it makes the API harder to
use for unfamiliar users.  For comparison:

actor.send_message(CreateSoldier())
actor >> CreateSoldier()

I'm not sure how I feel, so I'm going to test drive it for a while.

Make the Message class a bit more user-friendly.

This commit makes two small changes to the Message class:

1. Have messages specify tokens to add by reimplementing a method rather
   than adding to a list.  This change is primarily driven by security
   concerns.  However, it also removes all the state I'd added to
   Message, which makes more straightforward to subclass and pickle.

2. Have Message.on_check() raise if the check isn't passed.  This just
   makes sense, and should make messaging more intuitive for users.

Improve the ObjectNotFullyConstructed error message.

Previously, this error would call __repr__() on the object in question.
I realized that this was a bad idea because __repr__() might crash if
the object hasn't been fully constructed yet.
Allow AIs in quickstart sandbox games.

Store information about the GUI in Theater.

A few key GUI objects (e.g. the window) need to be shared between the
stages that make up the theater.  Previously, this information would be
manually passed between each stage.  This approach was always kinda
clunky, but it really became a problem for the quickstart code, because
it doesn't expose the stages to the user.

An alternative was to store these key GUI objects in the theater itself.
This makes sense because all the stages are using them anyways.  It also
works well with the quickstart code, because the stages no longer need
to explicitly configure each other.  The biggest drawback is that adding
implicit references to the GUI in the theater makes that class less
conceptually pure.  However, in this case I think pragmatism wins and
the additional responsibility of the Theater class is worth the decrease
in acrobatics that users have to go through to pass GUI objects around.

Theater can now be given an arbitrary "gui" object.  This object can be
accessed by any stage, and GameStage additionally makes it available to
each of its actors.  Quickstart.main() now requires a "gui" class.  If
the class provides an on_refresh_gui() method, it will be called before
and after the game as appropriate to clear the screen and to display any
"game over" messages set at the end of the game.

I thought a lot about providing a default "gui" object in quickstart
games, but ultimately I decided that this would it would just be easier
for players to write their own.  In other words, I didn't think a
default would provide enough features to justify the learning curve.

Allow tokens to subscribe using decorators.

I thought I had already tested this feature, but I had only been
subscribing in token superclass methods.  These methods aren't safety
checked by TokenMetaclass, so I didn't notice that the safety check was
covering up the subscription decorator flags.  The solution was to
simply copy the flags over using functools.update_wrapper().  This also
copies the name and module of the original function, which is an added
bonus.

This commit also adds the ability to subscribe to more than one message
type using decorators.

Save UsingRemovedToken magic before deleting it.

I will still check to see if expired tokens are being used in the
messaging system, but now I want to remove the checks the token class
itself makes.

Remove Token safety-check magic.

While trying to write tests for KOL, I found that the safety checks run
by the Token class really got in the way.  The checks are very thorough,
and they basically won't let you call any methods on a Token object
before it's been added to the world.

Here I decided to just completely get rid of the checks.  Now the Token
class is not magical at all.  I still check to make sure you don't send
messages about tokens that have been removed from the world, but you
could in principle have Actors modify the world and create sync issues,
or just completely neglect to add Tokens to the world at all.

Make ApiUsageError easier to use directly.

Before ApiUsageError was really just a backend for ApiUsageErrorFactory.
To report an error, you would subclass ApiUsageErrorFactory in errors.py
and raise your subclass wherever you needed to.

However, I now think it would be better to directly raise ApiUsageError
in most cases.  This puts the text of the error message at the same
place the error was detected, which serves as built-in documentation.
The ApiUsageErrorFactory is still useful for errors that can be
triggered in several different ways, but ApiUsageError is better for
one-off errors.
Describe what information errors should include.
Remove an unnecessary error-formatting corner-case.
Handle spaces in error summaries as in error details.
Add and test Message.tokens_referenced()
Correctly wrap numbered lists in error messages.

Move pre-world safety checks from tokens to messages.

Previously, tokens could be in three states with respect to the world:
before being added, currently participating, and after being removed.
The first and last states were distinguished only for the purpose of
error checking.

However, I decided that the "before being added" checks were too onerous
because they were getting in the way of unit tests for other games.  So
I combined the first and last states into one "not participating" state.
I removed any error checking the token does on itself when it's not
participating in the world, and instead added more error checking at the
point where tokens are being sent in messages.

The new participating and not participating states are not explicitly
represented.  Instead, they are implied by the value of Token.has_world.
Token.has_id is generally not checked and is assumed to be consistent
with Token.has_world.  I'm not sure this lack of explicit representation
is a good idea.  For example, if I want to write a unit test where a
token needs to use its world attribute, do I really want error checks?
That said, there's no proper way to even give a token a world attribute
without adding it to the world, and if you have a world object anyway,
it's not so hard to lock it temporarily.

This commit also streamlines how errors are reported to the user.
Before, it wasn't uncommon for the same error to be checked for in
several different places, all with several different error messages.
This was clearly a waste of effort.  It also made testing difficult
because it was sometimes difficult to trigger subtly different error
conditions, and often these conditions could only be triggered by
improperly calling private functions.

To improve this situation, I adopted the convention of using raising
ApiUsageError when an error is noticed for the first time. This is
usually in a public API function, and Actor.send_message() is especially
a hub for these checks.  In all other cases, I simply assert that the
expected condition is still satisfied, and provide a terse explanation
saying where the error should've been caught (with an ApiUsageError) if
the condition is not satisfied.

This way, users of the library should only ever see ApiUsageErrors, but
developers of the library may also see assertion errors.

Move World into tokens.py
Bump version: 0.1.2 → 0.2.0
Fix Travis CI and Coveralls badges.

Move the Theater and Stage classes to quickstart.

The Theater and Stage classes never really belonged in the core game
engine.  They manage the main loop rather than helping with networked
communication, and the core game engine should be agnostic to the main
loop.

When I added these classes, it was for reasons of convenience vs purity.
However, now the quickstart module provides convenience via a main loop
that is loop that is separate from the core game engine and that is not
required to be all that flexible.

The quickstart module is a more natural home for the Theater and Stage
classes, but until not I had not gotten around to moving them.  In fact,
I suspect that the Theater and Stage classes are more flexible than the
quickstart main loop requires, and that this flexibility might even be
to the detriment of features like pre- and post-game GUIs.
